title: 108_hr3613
content: The Act titled "Student Aid Streamlined Disclosure Act of 2003" requires disclosure of tax return information for student aid purposes. The Act "Student Aid Streamlined Disclosure Act of 2003" allows disclosure of tax return information for student financial assistance purposes, including taxpayer identity information and specific items in case of material discrepancies. The Act "Student Aid Streamlined Disclosure Act of 2003" permits disclosure of tax return details for student financial aid, including taxpayer identity and specific items in case of discrepancies in reported information to the Department of Education. The Act allows disclosure of tax return details to the Department of Education to determine discrepancies in reported information that could affect grants or loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Officers, employees, and contractors of the Department may disclose this information to contractors to assess potential over or under awards. Contractors of the Department of Education can disclose discrepancies in reported information for applications under the Higher Education Act of 1965, including whether items on tax returns are greater or less than reported to the Department. The Department of Education requires applicants to provide accurate information, including individuals with conflicting data and employees of institutions assisting with grants or loans. The Department of Education requires accurate information from applicants, including individuals with conflicting data and employees of institutions involved in grant or loan programs under Title IV of the Act. This information can only be disclosed to specific parties and cannot be fully redisclosed. Information with conflicting data can only be disclosed to the individual concerned and the Department of Justice for the purpose of collecting overpayments of grants or loans under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. disclosed information can only be used to verify reported information by relevant parties. The curr_chunk discusses the actions that can be taken in connection with applications for grants, loans, benefits, or work assistance under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, including determining income contingent repayment amounts, collecting overpayments, and auditing student assistance programs. The curr_chunk outlines the disclosure of information limited to tax years required for grant, loan, benefit, or work assistance under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The curr_chunk specifies eligibility criteria for income contingent repayment on student loans under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, based on dependency status. The curr_chunk defines "material discrepancy" as a significant difference between two sets of information, with specific thresholds based on the type of items being compared. The term 'applicable student loan' includes loans under specific programs in title IV of the Act, and exclusive authority is granted for certain disclosures under subsection (a). The disclosure covered in this paragraph pertains to funding agreements between the Secretary and the Secretary of Education for reimbursement of costs and monitoring compliance with a specific section. References to the Higher Education Act of 1965 in this paragraph shall be as in effect on the date of enactment. Requests for disclosures made after September 30, 2008, are not covered. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code are made to include subsection (13) in section 6103(a)(3) and make changes to section 6103(p). The amendments made by this section apply to requests for disclosures made after the date of the enactment of this Act, specifically modifying sections 6103(p) and 7213(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code.
